ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: After taking a year off from French, this course was an incredible re-emersion in a language that I love. I deepened my understanding of grammar topics that have eluded me in the past, and became a much more confident speaker and writer.
I developed my skills in and knowledge of advanced French grammar structures. I also developed insight and intuition in the French language.
this course has helped my see my limitation in not only the language but in learning the language

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The audio recordings I felt were not particularly helpful, and the course pack's exorbitant price is restrictive to those who have financial hardship, to be perfectly honest. It crams a little bit too much, and the structure of the course and the order of grammar does not make the most sense at times. It also seems highly dependent on the calibre of instructors to deliver the material effectively to be a good course.

My greatest frustration with this course was the fact that exams tended to come without much in-class preparation, and there was not always the chance to check the work that we had done, making it difficult to track our progress. I really enjoyed the WWII research project and would have loved more frequent creative projects during the semester. Additionally, I didnt always find the audio programs to be very helpful. Sometimes, they were difficult to make out due to the quality of the recording. I wish there had been a way to practice listening comprehension as opposed to simply repeating from the example. This being said, I enjoyed how much speaking aloud and answering questions we got to do during class time.

One strength of this course was its organization. Each lesson was introduced to the students both in written and auditory form for homework and then was reviewed during class, which worked for me. One weakness of this course is that feedback is not always provided for each lesson, making it hard to ensure that you understand the content.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This course is a must for anyone looking to become fluent in French.

This course does effectively help students advance their knowledge of the French language towards a more fluent state, so I would recommend this course to students who wish to become fluent in French. The first part of the semester is very heavy in grammar and the second part is very heavy in French readings, so if you strongly dislike one or the other then this is not the course for you. Also, there is approximately 2 hours of work for this class a night, which may be too much for some people. However, as someone interested in French, I did find the course very enjoyable and rewarding.
yes if they are interested in refining their french
